Langlois, also known as ComfyByTheFire, delivers The Immortal Lock, a gigantic custom level for Quake. They promote the horror-themed segmented map as a story-driven experience with \"extremely challenging fights\" in what might go down as the understatement of the century because this thing is absolutely crushing, even with a scalable difficulty selection.\n\nWhile The Immortal Lock utilizes the same weapons and enemy types from the original Quake files, the enormous interconnected level was created by seasoned modder ComfyByTheFire from scratch. The intention is to challenge even the most grizzled veterans who have mastered the classic FPS, filling its cosmic horror-laden halls with intricate platforming puzzles and hiding the necessary keys to unlock doors and progress forward.\n\nPlayers are gently encouraged to \"play one difficulty lower than you normally would,\" which should be enough of a hint of its unforgiving combat and relentless pitfalls dotted around its avenues of cosmic horrors.\n\nQuick-saves are your friends in The Immortal Lock, just as they were back in the late '90s before autosaves and regular cutscenes would save you from too much repetition. I spent a few hours getting acquainted with the surprising amount of interwoven story elements, mostly found as dropped notes from dead NPCs, and as a massive boomer shooter addict, I'm beyond hooked. Check out the trailer for a taste of its themes.\n\nInstalling The Immortal Lock on a Windows desktop or gaming laptop is about as simple as it gets. It doesn't require mod managers or a particular load order, only a legitimate copy of the game from Steam, GOG, or elsewhere. First, you need to install the original Quake and the vkQuake source port.\n\nYou could open vkQuake.exe at this point to test how the original Quake runs on your hardware. While it's a retro classic, vkQuake does enhance the engine with dynamic shadows and other visual luxuries, so it's worth checking that your PC is comfortable running the base game first. Now, let's install The Immortal Lock.\n\nAlternatively, if the 'Mods' option appears in your main menu upon launching Quake, you should be able to select 'immortal' from there, and it achieves the same outcome. Congratulations, you're about to jump into the pits of a secret research facility in.. Finland. Enjoying the mod? Let me know in the comments.\n\nYes, but it's far from perfect. While there is a native Linux port of vkQuake that handles Steam Deck controls without issue, the sheer enormity of The Immortal Lock causes some frame rate drops on Valve's handheld. Dropping the resolution to its bare minimum doesn't seem to affect the bad frame pacing in more demanding areas, but locking the maximum to 40 FPS can help with a smoother experience.\n\nHowever, when you reach areas with a screen full of active projectiles (and there are plenty of those), you'll likely struggle to hit all your shots with perfect accuracy, as the mod demands. If you have a Windows-based ASUS ROG Ally, you might have a better experience, but it is at least 'playable' on the Steam Deck, at least by Valve's verification standards. (It comes formatted for Macs, though you can use it with Windows, too.) We reviewed the 2TB version of the ArmorATD a few years back, and liked it. Prime Day sees a sale on the 5TB version, which is roomy for a portable hard drive. (It's also a lot cheaper than a 4TB or 8TB external SSD!) Hard drives are sensitive to drops and jolts, so opting for a model with a ruggedized frame or bumper like this one has is wise if you tend to use your drive in situations where rough handling is a possibility. You'll still want to treat it carefully, but the ArmorATD is tougher than most platter-based units. (See our review of the SanDisk Professional G-Drive Armor ATD.)\n\nPortable hard drives based on 2.5-inch internal platter mechanisms just recently hit a peak capacity of 6TB, so this deal on a 5TB model is for the kind of drive that, until not that long ago, was the roomiest around. We gave the My Passport 5TB an Editors' Choice award, in its time, for its then-top capacity and lightweight design. WD's supporting software is also a plus, and SSDs just can't touch this drive's cost per gigabyte of less than 3 cents. (See our review of the WD My Passport 5TB.)\n\nYou need to go all in on the T7 Shield only if you'll be taking your SSD places where most tech fears to tread. On-the-go photographers, field workers, and hopeless klutzes will want to give this tough drive a strong second look. It's a little costlier per gig than your typical external SSD, but if you can't put a value on your data, it's a bargain at any price -- and especially at this one. (See our review of the Samsung Portable SSD T7 Shield.)\n\nExternal drives for consumers that you'll see on Prime Day are split into two broad categories: external SSDs (which have no moving parts), and external platter hard drives (based on spinning mechanical disks). Within the hard drive class are portable USB-powered drives, as well as larger, AC-powered (but still USB-connected) desktop models. Portable hard drives are built around the 2.5-inch drive mechanisms that once were common in laptops, and these top out at 5TB or 6TB. Desktop drives employ meatier, but roomier, 3.5-inch mechanisms; most of these nowadays start at 8TB. When choosing between desktop and portable drives, consider whether you'll have your drive sit in one place all the time, or if it needs to come with you on the road (or even just around the house).\n\nMost mainstream external drives rely on the USB interface, in one of its myriad flavors. The drive may have a USB-A or USB-C connector at the computer end; many now come with both types of cables, or with an adapter. The nomenclature and nuances around USB speed specs are fussy stuff, so the best advice: Match the specific USB spec that the drive supports (say, \"USB 3.2 Gen 2\") with that of the fastest USB port on your PC or Mac. A few, usually pricey-per-gig, models employ the Thunderbolt 3 or 4 interface. Well, it works with everything (always lovely to see), with shortcuts and keys smartly tapping into platform features. With wired, wireless, Bluetooth, and the ability to switch between multiple devices - there's versatility here and then some.\n\nLow-profile keyboards are growing in popularity, at least in some circles. It's a style that's not for everyone because it traditionally replicates the feel of what you'd find with a laptop. Where keys sit relatively close to the PCB, and height-wise, keycaps are half the size or so of what you'd find on a traditional keyboard. The Willow Pro is still every bit a mechanical keyboard, and with Gateron switches, PBT keycaps with dye-sublimated legends, and pre-lubed stabilizers, it's got some chops.\n\nThat said, there's just something about the overall type-feel that isn't quite as impressive or satisfying as we've found in other recent low-profile efforts from ASUS and NuPhy. This is disappointing because the build quality is great, it looks fantastic, and the software support is decent for such a versatile unit. However, with the rise of 60, 75, and 80% keyboards in recent years, we've quietly begun to realize how massive full-sized keyboards can be and how much unnecessary space they can take up on a desk.\n\nThe physical design and layout of the Wombat Willow Pro Wireless Low Profile Mechanical Keyboard is a winner, but it's not for everybody. By making the keyboard taller, Wombat/KSI Keyboards fit all the functions and system keys above the main QWERTY layout while leaving enough room for the Numpad to sit above the arrow keys. The immediate productivity benefit is that the Numpad now sits close to the Enter key, so number crunchers can thumb it while efficiently typing in various numbers.\n\nThe layout does take some getting used to, thanks mainly to how it places keys like Del, End, and others in unusual places. But overall, it works great.\n\nBuilt for Mac, Windows, iOS, and Android, the Wombat Willow Pro adds impressive secondary functionality to streamline OS usage. That said, when it comes to the Gateron switches, although accurate, smooth, and mechanical in how they feel - there's some wobble and inconsistency between keys. Also, one minor feature that impressed me was the reversible magnetic feet, which allowed me to adjust the height of the keyboard between the default flat profile and one that is slightly raised.\n\nFor the Wombat Willow Pro Wireless Low Profile Mechanical Keyboard, the two rows of Function and System keys double as the programmable Macro keys, where you can assign secondary functions and small custom scripts. You can do this and record and store Macro sequences via the WB Pouch or Wombat Pouch software, available on both Mac and Windows. WB Pouch also offers automatic firmware updates for the Willow Pro, which is always handy when bugs are fixed before launch - as was the case here.\n\nWB Pouch is locked to a small resolution size and scale, so the layout is pretty small if you're running a 4K display. There are options to save settings to a file (or open them), with all changes being software-side until you download them onto the keyboard. The software is relatively easy to follow in that you've got three main sections: Macro, Backlit (for the RGB lighting), and Coding (a powerful but slow tool to program individual per-key RGB lighting and effects).\n\nMacro recording is a little clunky but works fine, with Wombat providing a quick online guide on using the tool. You have several intuitive pre-programmed options, including media and operating system calls, and you can assign Macros to all the keys on the top two rows. Overall, WB Pouch is a decent and welcome tool for those wanting to add app-specific functionality as Macros, as the overall keyboard design here leans more toward productivity than gaming.\n\nAlthough the keyboard sound isn't quite as satisfying as some, and there is some wobble, the linear Gateron switches and responsiveness with the Wombat Willow Pro Wireless Low Profile Mechanical Keyboard is perfectly fine for gaming on a Mac or PC. The Willow Pro features what Wombat calls REX 2.0 or 0 'RF EXtremely fast,' a low-latency wireless designed to mimic or match the low-latency performance you get from a wired USB connection. Regarding gaming, the REX 2.0 proved impressive as there wasn't any discernable difference between wired or wireless when playing Diablo 4, DOOM Eternal, and Apex Legends.\n\nAlthough we'd call the Willow Pro a compact keyboard, there's more than enough spacing between the keys for it not to feel cramped - and the total travel distance for the low-profile switches is more full-sized than a laptop. Minimal adjustment was required when moving from a standard keyboard to the low-profile Willow Pro for gaming. And you can chalk that up to the great-feeling keycaps and the high-performance Gateron switches.\n\nProductivity is where the Willow Pro shines; in addition to full Mac, iOS, Windows, and Android support, you can switch between multiple devices connected via Bluetooth (up to three), wireless, and wired. Battery life fares much better with the RGB lighting turned off (the Willow Pro has a 1000 mAh LiPO rechargeable battery), but it's enough to last multiple days of general usage, so it's not a big issue. Wombat provides easy device switching via secondary functionality on the Numpad, with a light indicator, making the whole process nice and smooth.\n\nNumpad lovers will love the overall Willow Pro layout and the quick access to common system tasks and tools via secondary functions and clearly labeled Macro keys. {"url": "https://au.pcmag.com/ssds/106319/last-chance-the-best-amazon-prime-day-deals-on-hard-drives-and-ssds", "title": "Last Chance: The Best Amazon Prime Day Deals on Hard Drives and SSDs", "body": "Buying the best-value external hard drive or SSD is, strictly speaking, a numbers game. The biggest numbers in play? The first is the price you pay on any given day for the drive you're considering. Even with Amazon Prime Day 2024 officially over, it's still one of the best times of the summer, let alone the year, to make your move.\n\nThe second number to look out for is the capacity of the drive, in gigabytes. Simple math will tell you how much you're paying per gigabyte, which is an excellent yardstick for measuring whether a drive is a scorcher of a deal or a just \"meh\" one.\n\nThose are not the only numbers to know, though. Also look at the length of the warranty for any drive you're eyeing. Plus -- and here's where yours truly, the PCMag experts, come in -- check out formal speed-test numbers from reputable third-party review sites. We'll toot our horn: We test dozens of external drives every year, both classic platter-based hard drives and speedy, compact solid-state models. A low cost per gigabyte, plus a warranty plan you can live with and a speed rating high enough for the kinds of stuff you store, together add up to the right external drive for your laptop or desktop.\n\nDeals on external storage move whip-fast in and out of \"good deal\" and \"great deal\" territory -- the very best ones don't stick around for long. That's because everybody loves more gigabytes. Here are some of the best deals we've seen for Prime Day on the top drives we've tested. (Looking for something more fun than storage and backup? We've got plenty of other excellent tech deals you can still grab after Prime Day ends.)\n\nSuperbly suited for pro content creators and mainstream users alike, the Samsung SSD Portable T9 is not only a Prime Day deal, but it's a great external SSD at any price. With the T9, you can expect 10Gbps speeds with the USB-C ports on most laptops and desktops. And if you're fortunate enough to have a USB-C port that supports USB 3.2 Gen 2x2, you could see up to double that. The drive comes in capacities up to 4TB, and it supports 256-bit AES hardware-based encryption in the event it falls into the wrong hands. It's also drop-proof and equipped with Samsung's polished, handy Magician software utility. (See our review of the Samsung Portable SSD T9.)\n\nHere's one for the Apple crowd. (It comes formatted for Macs, though you can use it with Windows, too.) We reviewed the 2TB version of the ArmorATD a few years back, and liked it. Prime Day sees a sale on the 5TB version, which is roomy for a portable hard drive. (It's also a lot cheaper than a 4TB or 8TB external SSD!) Hard drives are sensitive to drops and jolts, so opting for a model with a ruggedized frame or bumper like this one has is wise if you tend to use your drive in situations where rough handling is a possibility. You'll still want to treat it carefully, but the ArmorATD is tougher than most platter-based units. (See our review of the SanDisk Professional G-Drive Armor ATD.)\n\nPortable hard drives based on 2.5-inch internal platter mechanisms just recently hit a peak capacity of 6TB, so this deal on a 5TB model is for the kind of drive that, until not that long ago, was the roomiest around. We gave the My Passport 5TB an Editors' Choice award, in its time, for its then-top capacity and lightweight design. WD's supporting software is also a plus, and SSDs just can't touch this drive's cost per gigabyte of less than 3 cents. (See our review of the WD My Passport 5TB.)\n\nYou need to go all in on the T7 Shield only if you'll be taking your SSD places where most tech fears to tread. This drive has a rubbery wrapper that keeps it safe in the event of tumbles, rain, and other environmental invaders. Indeed, the T7 Shield is rated for dust- and water-resistance that should suffice for most casual (or should we say careless?) use. On-the-go photographers, field workers, and hopeless klutzes will want to give this tough drive a strong second look. It's a little costlier per gig than your typical external SSD, but if you can't put a value on your data, it's a bargain at any price -- and especially at this one. (See our review of the Samsung Portable SSD T7 Shield.)\n\nExternal drives for consumers that you'll see on Prime Day are split into two broad categories: external SSDs (which have no moving parts), and external platter hard drives (based on spinning mechanical disks). Within the hard drive class are portable USB-powered drives, as well as larger, AC-powered (but still USB-connected) desktop models. Portable hard drives are built around the 2.5-inch drive mechanisms that once were common in laptops, and these top out at 5TB or 6TB. Desktop drives employ meatier, but roomier, 3.5-inch mechanisms; most of these nowadays start at 8TB. When choosing between desktop and portable drives, consider whether you'll have your drive sit in one place all the time, or if it needs to come with you on the road (or even just around the house).\n\nMost mainstream external drives rely on the USB interface, in one of its myriad flavors. The drive may have a USB-A or USB-C connector at the computer end; many now come with both types of cables, or with an adapter. The nomenclature and nuances around USB speed specs are fussy stuff, so the best advice: Match the specific USB spec that the drive supports (say, \"USB 3.2 Gen 2\") with that of the fastest USB port on your PC or Mac. A few, usually pricey-per-gig, models employ the Thunderbolt 3 or 4 interface. {"url": "https://www.lesnumeriques.com/antivirus/vrai-ou-faux-les-ordinateurs-sous-mac-et-linux-ont-ils-besoin-d-un-antivirus-n224479.html", "title": "Vrai ou faux : Les ordinateurs sous Mac et Linux ont-ils besoin d'un antivirus ?", "body": "Vous possédez un ordinateur sous Linux ou Mac OS et vous pensez être à l'abri de toute attaque de virus, malwares, ransomwares et autres programmes malveillants ? On vous dit tout !\n\nIl y a moins de virus et de malwares compatibles avec les systèmes d'exploitation Mac et Linux, car il y a moins d'utilisateurs que pour Windows et donc moins de cibles potentielles pour les hackers. Il y a des protections intégrées par Apple sur ses machines et Linux est un système plus stable que Windows, donc moins de vulnérabilités...\n\nTout le monde a déjà entendu ces adages depuis de nombreuses années, en se disant \"c'est logique\", mais qu'en est-il vraiment ? Ces affirmations sont-elles toujours vraies en 2024 ? Quelles sont les meilleures solutions antivirus pour votre ordinateur, que vous soyez sous Windows, Mac ou Linux ?\n\nLes meilleurs antivirus pour Mac\n\nCette croyance repose en grande partie sur l'idée que ces systèmes d'exploitation sont nativement sécurisés et que les menaces de cybersécurité se concentrent principalement sur les utilisateurs de Windows. Or, cette idée, plutôt simpliste, mais logique, ne résiste pas à une analyse approfondie et surtout ne s'adapte pas à toutes les situations.\n\nTout d'abord, il est important de comprendre que macOS et Linux sont effectivement conçus avec des mécanismes de sécurité robustes. Le système Unix, sur lequel ces deux systèmes sont basés, comporte des fonctionnalités de sécurité intégrées telles que la gestion stricte des permissions des fichiers et des utilisateurs, ce qui limite les possibilités d'exécution de programmes malveillants. Cependant, ces protections ne sont pas infaillibles. Les pirates informatiques cherchent constamment des moyens de contourner les barrières, et aucune architecture n'est à l'abri des failles.\n\nLes utilisateurs de macOS, par exemple, bénéficient de la réputation de sécurité d'Apple, mais les macs sont de plus en plus populaires, et cette popularité attire inévitablement l'attention des cybercriminels. Les logiciels malveillants ciblant spécifiquement macOS se multiplient, et les campagnes de phishing ne font pas de distinction entre les systèmes d'exploitation. De plus, se croyant à l'abri de toute menace avec Apple, certains utilisateurs peuvent négliger certaines bonnes pratiques de sécurité informatique, comme l'installation de mises à jour (sauf si vous activez la mise à jour automatique) ou l'utilisation d'un gestionnaire de mots de passe forts.\n\nLinux, souvent perçu comme le domaine des experts en informatique, n'est pas non plus exempt de risques. Bien que sa structure ouverte et sa base d'utilisateurs plus technique puissent décourager certains pirates, le fait que de nombreux serveurs et infrastructures professionnels fonctionnent sous Linux en font une cible de choix. Les distributions Linux varient en termes de configuration de sécurité par défaut, et les utilisateurs peuvent involontairement créer des vulnérabilités en personnalisant leur environnement ou en installant des logiciels de sources non vérifiées. De plus, les attaques ne se limitent pas aux logiciels malveillants traditionnels ; les attaques de type \"zero-day\", les exploits de réseau, et les attaques par force brute sont tout aussi préoccupantes pour les systèmes Linux.\n\nUne autre dimension importante est la protection contre les menaces au-delà des simples virus. Les ransomwares et les tentatives de phishing peuvent affecter n'importe quel système. La connectivité constante à Internet, l'usage de services en ligne et le partage de fichiers augmentent les risques de vol de données. Les utilisateurs de macOS et Linux peuvent être victimes de ces types d'attaques, souvent par le biais de failles de sécurité non corrigées, de piratage de compte ou d'arnaques au conseiller bancaire. Un bon logiciel antivirus ne se contente pas de détecter et de supprimer les virus ; il offre également une couche de protection contre une gamme plus large de menaces, incluant les logiciels malveillants polymorphes, les tentatives d'hameçonnage et les attaques basées sur des scripts.\n\nL'idée que les ordinateurs sous macOS et Linux n'ont pas besoin d'antivirus repose donc sur une compréhension incomplète et dépassée des menaces modernes. La sécurité informatique est un domaine en constante évolution, et aucun système n'est totalement à l'abri. Une approche proactive, incluant l'utilisation de logiciels antivirus, la mise à jour régulière des systèmes et des applications, la sauvegarde régulière de vos données et la vigilance quant aux comportements en ligne, sont essentielles pour se protéger efficacement.\n\nAprès ce constat, il est donc recommandé d'installer un antivirus, quel que soit le système d'exploitation de votre ordinateur. D'autant plus qu'aujourd'hui, les antivirus sont plus légers et consomment moins de ressources, bien loin de leur réputation d'usine à gaz des années 2000.\n\nQuel que soit le système d'exploitation dont vous disposez, il est conseillé de faire appel à un éditeur de solution de sécurité réputé. Pour Mac OS X, vous pouvez faire confiance au laboratoire de test indépendant AV-Test qui met au banc d'essai de nombreux antivirus pour en évaluer les performances, le niveau de protection et la simplicité d'utilisation. Parmi eux se distinguent ces 3 solutions. Passons en revue leurs avantages et leurs fonctionnalités.\n\nAvast One Gold est une solution de sécurité efficace pour les ordinateurs sous macOS, offrant une protection en temps réel contre les malwares et les menaces émergentes. Le logiciel est conçu pour détecter spécifiquement les malwares propres à macOS, avec des mises à jour régulières de sa base de données pour rester efficace contre les nouvelles menaces. En plus de la détection de malwares, Avast One Gold analyse les fichiers et les applications pour repérer les comportements suspects et les logiciels potentiellement indésirables.", "source": {"uri": "lesnumeriques.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Les Numériques"}, "authors": [], "image": "https://cdn.lesnumeriques.com/optim/news/22/224479/df50f854-vrai-ou-faux-les-ordinateurs-sous-mac-et-linux-ont-ils-besoin-d-un-antivirus__1200_678__0-62-1920-1070.jpg", "eventUri": null, "sentiment": null, "wgt": 459009073, "relevance": 100}

(See our review of the Samsung Portable SSD T7 Shield.)\n\nExternal drives for consumers that you'll see on Prime Day are split into two broad categories: external SSDs (which have no moving parts), and external platter hard drives (based on spinning mechanical disks). Within the hard drive class are portable USB-powered drives, as well as larger, AC-powered (but still USB-connected) desktop models. Portable hard drives are built around the 2.5-inch drive mechanisms that once were common in laptops, and these top out at 5TB or 6TB. Desktop drives employ meatier, but roomier, 3.5-inch mechanisms; most of these nowadays start at 8TB. When choosing between desktop and portable drives, consider whether you'll have your drive sit in one place all the time, or if it needs to come with you on the road (or even just around the house).\n\nMost mainstream external drives rely on the USB interface, in one of its myriad flavors. The drive may have a USB-A or USB-C connector at the computer end; many now come with both types of cables, or with an adapter. The nomenclature and nuances around USB speed specs are fussy stuff, so the best advice: Match the specific USB spec that the drive supports (say, \"USB 3.2 Gen 2\") with that of the fastest USB port on your PC or Mac. A few, usually pricey-per-gig, models employ the Thunderbolt 3 or 4 interface. Здесь не будет текста правил, но будет всё для того, чтобы самостоятельно перенести детектирующую логику в используемые вами продукты. Предлагаемые нами методы мониторинга рассчитаны в основном на базовую телеметрию,но и она позволяет поймать Змия за хвост :).\n\nОтдельно отметим, что у предложенной в статье логики детектирования могут быть ложные срабатывания, связанные в том числе со стандартным поведением системы, поэтому она потребует тонкой настройки (в том числе фильтрации) под вашу инфраструктуру.\n\nДалее мы опишем уязвимости, использованные группировкой Shedding Zmiy. С признаками эксплуатации некоторых из них команда 4RAYS столкнулась, распутывая змеиный клубок атак Shedding Zmiy (кейсы 1, 3, 4, 6, 7). Однако анализ тактик, техник и процедур, использованных группировкой, позволяет утверждать, что инструментарий злоумышленников шире и включает в себя многие известные в коммьюнити уязвимости трёх последних лет.\n\nЗаранее оговоримся, что в большинстве случаев главной рекомендацией будет своевременное обновление продуктов и установка вендорских патчей.\n\nNB! Можно использовать polkit для выполнения команд с повышенными привилегиями, используя команду pkexec, за которой следует команда, предназначенная для выполнения с правами root.\n\nСуть уязвимости - memory corruption, связанная с фиксированным размером буфера argv[] для pkexec. Если оставить буфер пустым (то есть, запустить команду без параметров), при чтении argv[0] будет получен NULL, который в свою очередь является escape-последовательностью для списка аргументов argv. Таким образом, мы уже вышли за пределы этого буфера (out-of-bounds) и начали читать следующий за ним envp.\n\nЗлоумышленник может разместить в буфере envp путь к своей полезной нагрузке в переменной PATH, и, так как pkexec был запущен без параметров и обладает suid, нагрузка по пути PATH будет выполнена с повышенными привилегиями.\n\nПрисмотритесь к вызову pkexec без аргументов, для этого вам потребуется мониторинг запуска процесса (и мониторинг его параметров):\n\nКроме того, можно поискать в логе артефакты выполнения pkexec:\n\n\"The value for the SHELL variable was not found the /etc/shells file\",\n\n\"The value for environment variable [...] contains suspicious content\"\n\nTale as old as time. {"url": "https://www.cnews.ru/news/top/2024-07-18_windows_budet_obnovlyatsya_po-novomu", "title": "В Windows появился принципиально новый механизм обновления. Апдейты станут легче и безопаснее, но пользователи ждут подвоха", "body": "Microsoft решила поменять принцип обновления Windows. Отныне она будет выпускать несколько \"накопительных обновлений с контрольной точкой\". Они будет иметь небольшой \"вес\" и будут загружаться в фоне, без дополнительных действий со стороны пользователей. Но пользователи считают, что благодарить Microsoft за новый подход к обновлению Windows пока рано - они прогнозируют массу потенциальных проблем, которые он может вызвать.\n\nMicrosoft внедряет новый принцип обновления ОС Windows, основанный на \"накопительных апдейтах с контрольной точкой\" (checkpoint cumulative updates). Нововведение станет доступно пользователям Windows 11 с релизом версии 24Н2 ближе к концу 2024 г., а также в Windows Server 2025.\n\nНовый подход заключается в том, что сами обновления будут \"весить\" меньше - система будет загружать только те патчи, которые вышли после даты контрольной точки, созданной при последнем обновлении. По задумке Microsoft, это упростит и ускорит процесс обновления, а также сделает его еще менее заметным для пользователя, так как, по плану, все патчи будут загружаться и устанавливаться в фоновом режиме.\n\nMicrosoft утверждает, что переход на новый механизм обновления позволит пользователям не только тратить меньше трафика на загрузку патчей, но и сэкономить место на жестком диске в сравнении с тем, как Windows обновляется сейчас. Напомним, что Microsoft выпускает довольно крупные накопительные апдейты по вторникам, которые могут содержать в себе ранее скачанные и установленные обновления и оттого \"весят\" сравнительно много.\n\nПри этом Microsoft до сих пор не предлагает пользователям инструменты по \"расхламлению\" Windows 11, хотя эта система потребляет неоправданно много места на системном диске. Владельцам ПК на ее основе приходится или мириться с десятками гигабайт в папке Windows, или использовать сторонний софт для удаления из нее ненужного мусора.\n\nMicrosoft утверждает, что механизм загрузки только тех обновлений, которых еще нет в системе, несет в себе массу дополнительных преимуществ, помимо снижения расхода трафика и места на системном диске. В частности, компания указывает, что сможет быстрее выпускать патч для устранения той или иной новой проблемы.\n\nСейчас это действительно является проблемой. Нередко случается так, что пользователям приходится ждать в течение нескольких недель, пока Microsoft напишет заплатку для очередной проблемы в Windows, и пока она получит широкое распространение. Очень часто это касается и очень крупных сбоев, а не только мелких недочетов.\n\nКак пишет портал TechSpot, Microsoft хоть еще и не внедрила свою инновацию в Windows, но уже успела перепугать некоторых пользователей. Они открыто выразили свою обеспокоенность - по их словам, новая технология доставки обновлений еще \"сырая\".\n\nПо мнению одного из пользователей, если после вступления изменений в силу с одним из накопительных обновлений возникнет какая-либо проблема при установке, то его новые апдейты могут перестать поступать на ПК.\n\nЕще одно беспокойство заключается в том, что накопительные обновления с контрольной точкой не упростят, а, наоборот, усложнят и без того запутанный процесс обновления Windows. Для примера, глобальный апдейт 23Н2 Microsoft выпустила еще осенью 2023 г., однако лишь 18 июля 2024 г. он стал доступен всем пользователям Windows 11 (кроме россиян). То есть Microsoft потребовалось более полугода, чтобы наладить распространение этого пакета.\n\nПользователи также всерьез опасаются, что новая система доставки патчей может усложнить процесс отката до предыдущей контрольной точки, если возникнут проблемы в работе системы после установки нового обновления. К тому же всегда есть вероятность конфликтов между различными обновлениями контрольных точек или с существующими конфигурациями системы, считают эксперты TechSpot.\n\nЖелающие поскорее опробовать новую систему обновлений Windows вполне могут не дожидаться релиза апдейта 24Н2, интегрирующего ее в операционную систему. По данным портала TechSpot, новшество уже доступно участникам бета-тестирования.\n\nИзменения внедрены в состав тестовой сборки 26120.1252. Напомним, что россияне по решению Microsoft официально лишены права участвовать в программе тестирования Windows Insider с лета 2022 г.", "source": {"uri": "cnews.ru", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNews.ru"}, "authors": [], "image": "https://static.cnews.ru/img/news/2024/02/13/win6.jpg", "eventUri": "rus-1699293", "sentiment": null, "wgt": 459008586, "relevance": 50}

{"url": "https://www.cronista.com/infotechnology/actualidad/gmail-la-solucion-para-liberar-espacio-en-tu-cuenta-para-siempre-facil-y-gratis/", "title": "Gmail: la solución para liberar espacio en tu cuenta para siempre, fácil y gratis", "body": "El servicio de correo electrónico gratuito Gmail es el más utilizado en el mundo, pero su espacio de almacenamiento es limitado y se comparte con otros servicios online de Google. Debido a esto, la capacidad que brinda nunca resulta suficiente y los usuarios siempre buscan una solución duradera a ese problema.\n\nHay que considerar que una cuenta de Google solo incluye un espacio de almacenamiento de 15 GB de manera gratuita. Esa cantidad suele ser suficiente para Gmail solo, pero lo cierto es que el espacio se comparte también con apps y servicios como Google Drive y Google Fotos. Y, actualmente, incluso se utiliza para los backups del mensajero WhatsApp.\n\nAunque Google brinda planes de pago con mayor capacidad de almacenamiento, lo cierto es que existen otras formas de obtener más lugar para los correos o archivos sin necesidad de pagar. A continuación, se detallan las 4 principales.\n\nLa aplicación Google Drive permite controlar el almacenamiento de la cuenta de Google, lo que puede resultar en una mejoría notable en el espacio disponible en Gmail.\n\nEn la nueva pantalla que surge, hay que encontrar y presionar el botón \"Libera espacio\". A partir de ese momento, el sistema analizará los contenidos de la cuenta de Google y guiará al usuario para eliminar los archivos más grandes.\n\nAsimismo, es posible elegir recuperar espacio de manera selectiva solo en algunos de los servicios de Google. Entre ellos se listan Gmail, Google Drive y Google Fotos. Si presionamos sobre la primera alternativa, veremos que se presentan los correos que incluyen archivos adjuntos de gran tamaño, para que podamos borrarlos y ganar capacidad.\n\nUna cuenta de email de Gmail con varios años de antigüedad puede contener una cantidad asombrosa de mensajes que ya no importan ni contienen información útil. Una gran parte de de ellos, probablemente, integren también archivos adjuntos, lo que acrecienta el problema.\n\nPara eliminar los correos viejos también se puede utilizar el buscador avanzado de Gmail, que permite especificar un intervalo de fechas.\n\nY no hay que olvidar el vaciar la papelera de Gmail, aunque se borra automáticamente cada 30 días. Asimismo, es clave ver que no haya mucho correo acumulado en la carpeta de spam.\n\nGmail posee un buscador que, en sus opciones avanzadas, permite filtrar los correos que tienen archivos adjuntos y también especificar su peso. Se puede experimentar con valores altos, como 10 MB, para detectar fácilmente cuáles son los mensajes que más espacio ocupan en nuestra cuenta.\n\nLos correos guardados en la cuenta de Gmail se pueden descargar fácilmente a una computadora de escritorio mediante un cliente de correo. Entre los típicos programas de este estilo se encuentra Outlook de Microsoft (ya instalado de manera predeterminada en muchas PCs con Windows) y Thunderbird (gratuito y muy recomendado).\n\nCada vez que un cliente externo de este tipo accede a la cuenta de Gmail, comienza a bajar primero los correos más antiguos. A medida que son descargados, estos correos se borran automáticamente de Gmail y pasan a la papelera. Luego hay que vaciar la papelera para ganar realmente ese espacio.\n\nAunque configurar este tipo de clientes de correo no es tan fácil, el esfuerzo, a la larga, vale la pena. Para poder usarlos, hay que ingresar en ellos la dirección de correo de Gmail, el usuario y la contraseña.\n\nTambién, en la configuración de Gmail hay que ingresar en el apartado POP/IMAP, habilitar la opción \"POP download\" y, en otra opción justo por debajo, se debe habilitar que los correos sean borrados una vez que se completa su descarga.", "source": {"uri": "cronista.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "El Cronista"}, "authors": [], "image": "https://www.cronista.com/files/image/455/455747/624c526e4f13a_600_315!.jpg?s=1aa2cd2f93741994d87eaf56be471a7c&d=1721310814", "eventUri": null, "sentiment": null, "wgt": 459008196, "relevance": 1}

{"url": "https://www.osnews.com/story/140258/unified-kernel-image/", "title": "Unified kernel image", "body": "UKIs can run on UEFI systems and simplify the distribution of small kernel images. For example, they simplify network booting with iPXE. UKIs make rootfs and kernels composable, making it possible to derive a rootfs for multiple kernel versions with one file for each pair.\n\nA Unified Kernel Image (UKI) is a combination of a UEFI boot stub program, a Linux kernel image, an initramfs, and further resources in a single UEFI PE file (device tree, cpu µcode, splash screen, secure boot sig/key, ...). This file can either be directly invoked by the UEFI firmware or through a boot loader.\n\n↫ Hugues\n\nIf you're still a bit unfamiliar with unified kernel images, this post contains a ton of detailed practical information. Unified kernel images might become a staple for forward-looking Linux distributions, and I know for a fact that my distribution of choice, Fedora, has been working on it for a while now. The goal is to eventually simplify the boot process as a whole, and make better, more optimal use of the advanced capabilities UEFI gives us over the old, limited, 1980s BIOS model.\n\nLike I said a few posts ago, I really don't want to be using traditional bootloaders anymore. UEFI is explicitly designed to just boot operating systems on its own, and modern PCs just don't need bootloaders anymore. They're points of failure users shouldn't be dealing with anymore in 2024, and I'm glad to see the Linux world is seriously moving towards negating the need for their existence.", "source": {"uri": "osnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "OSNews: Exploring the Future of Computing"}, "authors": [{"uri": "thom_holwerda@osnews.com", "name": "Thom Holwerda", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "image": null, "eventUri": null, "sentiment": 0.2313725490196079, "wgt": 459007860, "relevance": 1}

(See our review of the Samsung Portable SSD T7 Shield.)\n\nThe Two Main Kinds of Drive: HDDs and SSDs\n\nExternal drives for consumers that you'll see on Prime Day are split into two broad categories: external SSDs (which have no moving parts), and external platter hard drives (based on spinning mechanical disks). Within the hard drive class are portable USB-powered drives, as well as larger, AC-powered (but still USB-connected) desktop models. Portable hard drives are built around the 2.5-inch drive mechanisms that once were common in laptops, and these top out at 5TB or 6TB. Desktop drives employ meatier, but roomier, 3.5-inch mechanisms; most of these nowadays start at 8TB. When choosing between desktop and portable drives, consider whether you'll have your drive sit in one place all the time, or if it needs to come with you on the road (or even just around the house).\n\nMost mainstream external drives rely on the USB interface, in one of its myriad flavors. The nomenclature and nuances around USB speed specs are fussy stuff, so the best advice: Match the specific USB spec that the drive supports (say, \"USB 3.2 Gen 2\") with that of the fastest USB port on your PC or Mac. {"url": "https://www.xatakandroid.com/tutoriales/pulsar-boton-tener-ram-posible-tu-movil-xiaomi-este-truco-hyperos", "title": "Pulsar un botón y tener más RAM es posible en tu móvil Xiaomi con este truco de HyperOS", "body": "Mi primer móvil Android tenía 512 MB de RAM y llegó un punto en que cada vez que abría WhatsApp tenía que forzar el cierre del resto de apps. Hoy en día los móviles tienen mucha más RAM pero hay veces en las que no puede ser suficiente. Si tienes un móvil Xiaomi, Redmi o POCO con HyperOS, puedes aumentar RAM en un par de segundos.\n\nNo necesitas desatornillar el móvil ni hacer nada, salvo aprovechar una función de HyperOS que es bastante habitual hoy en día en muchos móviles: la memoria virtual. HyperOS (y antiguamente MIUI) llama a esto extensión de memoria.\n\nLos móviles tienen cada vez más RAM pero también hay aplicaciones y juegos que requieren de más RAM. Una posible solución o, al menos un parche para salir del paso, es usar la memoria virtual. Esto significa que parte del almacenamiento de tu móvil se usa como memoria RAM, de forma similar a como pasa en Windows.\n\nLa memoria RAM es volátil: se usa temporalmente para almacenar los datos de las aplicaciones que se usan. Android se encarga de gestionar y reciclar esta memoria para que rara vez nos quedemos sin memoria. En el caso de que nos quedemos sin memoria, Android se encarga de cerrar aplicaciones en segundo plano para hacer espacio.\n\nPuede haber casos en los que la memoria de tu móvil se quede corta. Especialmente si juegas a juegos AAA que consumen muchos recursos en el móvil y tu móvil tiene \"solo\" 3, 4 o 6 GB de RAM. En ese caso las capas de Android como HyperOS te permiten usar almacenamiento interno como RAM. Pierdes almacenamiento, ganas en RAM.\n\nLa RAM virtual nos ayuda a que Android tenga disponible más memoria y potencialmente pueda cerrar las aplicaciones de forma menos agresiva (otra cosa es que lo siga haciendo por ahorrar batería), pero no es igual de rápida que la real. No obstante, el sistema es lo suficientemente inteligente para usar primero con la memoria RAM real antes de usar la virtual, así que activar la memoria virtual no tiene ningún inconveniente más allá de que pierdes espacio de almacenamiento.\n\nEl mayor impedimento es que puede ser difícil encontrar cómo se hace esto en HyperOS en tu móvil Xiaomi, POCO o Redmi, pues está un poco escondido. Los pasos son los siguientes:\n\nY ya está, tu móvil de 4 GB ahora puede tener por ejemplo unos 6 GB de memoria, 4 reales y 2 virtuales. {"url": "https://www.pcmag.com/how-to/what-to-do-if-your-headphones-or-speakers-sound-terrible", "title": "What to Do If Your Headphones or Speakers Sound Terrible", "body": "There's no feeling like turning on your new high-end computer speakers or noise-cancelling headphones, only to hear crackling static instead of crisp music. However, before blaming your audio peripherals for the garbled mess in your ears, it might also be the computer or phone that's to blame. If your audio has a bad case of the snap-crackle-pops, here are a few ways to troubleshoot the problem.\n\n1. Lower the Volume\n\nYou might want to enjoy your new speaker, but if it distorts at loud volumes, it might just not have enough power for the space. Turn the volume down and see if the music still sounds distorted. If it sounds okay, your speaker is probably just underpowered for that volume level.\n\n2. Check Your Source Files\n\nNext, check the quality of the music itself. For streaming services like Spotify, make sure you have the audio-quality setting as high as it goes for the best sounding music. For lossless audio, Apple Music and Tidal are your best options, while Amazon Music Ultimate costs extra for better music quality.\n\nIf you're trying to play music that you own, remember to only grab songs from trusted sources. For those with a large CD collection, rip the disc and go digital. If it's music bought from iTunes or Amazon, you can be reasonably assured the songs are a decent quality.\n\nHowever, if you're listening to an 80kbps MP3 downloaded from KaZaA in the early 2000s -- or worse, streaming a YouTube video of a song someone else downloaded from KaZaA in the early 2000s -- there are no settings you can tweak to make it sound good.\n\n3. Look for Dirt or Water Damage\n\nIf your problems seem tied to one specific speaker or set of headphones, it could have water damage, dirt, or other debris keeping the speaker from producing clear audio. This is especially common in the built-in speakers on smartphones, so grab a toothpick and clean out any gunk you see. Those with AirPods can follow our cleaning guide.\n\nIf your iPhone recently took a dip in the pool, there's an Apple Shortcut that can help get the water out. Otherwise, just give the phone time to dry. However, keep in mind that nothing lasts forever. A modern smartphone can survive a splashing -- or even a dunking -- but dropping it into the ocean is another story. Waterproof headphones do exist, but you'll probably need to buy a new pair if they go through the wash.\n\n4. Try a Different Port (If You Can)\n\nIf you use Bluetooth headphones, try a wired pair or use the cable that came with them, if they support both. If you have wired headphones, try with a Bluetooth pair if one is available. This will help determine if the issue is with Bluetooth, the cable, or the headphones themselves.\n\nDesktop PCs are not usually known for having the best audio quality on the front headphone jack. (That's why many audiophiles use DACs, separate digital-to-analog converters.) If things sound less than stellar, try plugging the headphones into the speaker jack on the back of your PC to see if that improves anything.\n\nLaptops won't have another headphone jack (or any at all), but you could try connecting them with a USB dongle to see if you notice any differences. Depending on the computer model, you may need a 3.5mm-to-USB-C or 3.5mm-to-USB-A adapter.\n\nThe problem could also be with the jack itself, or with the audio drivers governing the PC's onboard audio. If it's the latter case, try reinstalling the drivers to see if that helps.\n\n5. Disable Phone Calls on Your Headphones\n\nLet's assume everything is good on the hardware side: Now it's time to dig into the audio settings. If your earbuds double as a headset for phone calls, it's possible the device is sending audio using the inferior phone call path rather than treating them as high-quality stereo headphones.\n\nIn Windows 10, open Settings > Sound > Sound Control Panel to see a list of all the speakers, headphones, and unused audio ports on your machine. Those with Windows 11 should go to Settings > System > Sound > More sound settings. Look for the device with a green checkmark -- the one you're currently using -- and make sure it's the correct one.\n\nIf you have a set of wireless headphones with a built-in microphone, it may produce two entries in this list -- one as a stereo set of headphones, and one as a hands-free headset designed for phone calls. If you play music through the virtual device designed for phone calls, it will sound terrible, so select different items here and click Set Default to see if one option sounds better than another. (You can also disable the communications headset option completely.)\n\nThis is a common issue on Windows machines, but less so on phones. Still, it doesn't hurt to check. On Android, go into the Bluetooth settings, tap the settings cog next to the headphones in question, and turn calls off to see if that solves the problem. On an iPhone, click the \"i\" next to your headphones in Bluetooth settings and change the Device type to see if that does anything.\n\n6. Adjust Your Equalizer and Audio Enhancements\n\nMany phones and PCs have some audio \"enhancements\" that can be added to your music, though these can often do more harm than good. If you're hearing distortion, make sure all of these settings are turned off. In Windows, head back to the Sound Settings as described above. Then, right-click the device from the list and click the Properties button\n\nGo through any Enhancements, Advanced, or Spatial Sound tabs you see to turn off features like Spatial Sound or Bass Boost. All of these things can, in theory, cause distortion in the audio. You might even try turning Exclusive Mode on or off, to see if that solves any issues.\n\nIf your problems are on an iPhone, head to Settings > Music and make sure the EQ is turned off. Do the same for the music app you're using to listen. Android users will need to turn to their specific music app of choice, though Samsung devices may have other audio enhancements in settings. Search for features like Dolby Atmos, Equalizers, Adapt Sound, and other improvements that could be causing problems.\n\nYou may also want to change the audio codec used for Bluetooth devices. iPhone owners should be using headphones that support AAC, while Android users should use AptX. In Android, open Bluetooth settings, click the cog next to your headphones, and try the higher-quality AAC or aptX instead of the default setting, if given the option. On some phones, this will be called \"HD Audio.\"\n\n7. Disconnect Other Bluetooth Devices\n\nHow many Bluetooth devices have you connected to your phone? Are your headphones paired to your phone and computer at the same time? Sometimes, Bluetooth devices can interfere with one another, which will make music sound distorted, especially if audio is coming from multiple sources.\n\nCheck the Bluetooth settings on your computer or phone and disconnect any secondary devices that may have automatically connected. After clearing things out, your audio may come in cleaner in your main Bluetooth headphones. (For a smartwatch, you might be able to go into the watch's settings and turn off call and media audio.)", "source": {"uri": "pcmag.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PC Magazine"}, "authors": [{"uri": "whitson_gordon@pcmag.com", "name": "Whitson Gordon", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "image": "https://i.pcmag.com/imagery/articles/02UfFCtQzI7hfixDyfjr2mV-9.fit_lim.size_1200x630.v1619030735.jpg", "eventUri": null, "sentiment": -0.2235294117647059, "wgt": 459007633, "relevance": 13}

{"url": "https://www.techradar.com/computing/windows/windows-11-22h2-gets-one-final-push-by-microsoft-before-retirement-but-23h2-is-here-for-the-rescue", "title": "Windows 11 22H2 gets one final push by Microsoft before retirement - but 23H2 is here for the rescue", "body": "Windows 11 version 22H2 is finally available to download and install for all eligible Windows 11 users as of July 17, 2024 - just a few months before it's getting ditched by Microsoft. This final push might seem a little late in the day considering 22H2 is nearing its end of life date, and Microsoft is trying to encourage people to get the more recent Windows 11 23H2 update instead.\n\nNot only has it been nearly a year since 23H2's initial release, but Windows 11 22H2's end-of-support date is also quickly approaching. This isn't unusual, as every Windows product released has a product lifecycle, which is essentially a plan for the product's development, implementation, and, ultimately, its deprecation. 22H2's end-of-support date is set for October 8, 2024, and Microsoft will supposedly stop releasing monthly security patch updates for it after this date.\n\nMonthly security patches are important as both the tech companies that release them and industry experts recommend that you install them as soon as they're available as they contain protective measures to help secure your PC against newly devised attacks and address freshly discovered vulnerabilities. When Microsoft stops releasing these, any devices running 22H2 will be left at risk.\n\nFor this reason, devices running Windows 11 Home and Pro will be forced to update to 23H2 (unless they are managed by IT departments of organizations - then they might be exempt). After this happens, these devices will be eligible to receive the latest security patches for 23H2.\n\nWindows 11 23H2 is slated for an end-of-support date of November 11, 2025, and when compared to its predecessor 22H2, it also brings changes including taskbar regrouping that enables users to see each new app window as a separate icon, a new volume mixer which allows users to control the volume of various apps and playback devices more easily, and native 7Z and RAR file format support.\n\nThe broader availability of 22H2 was announced and further detailed on Microsoft's Learn blog. It's notable that 22H2's end-of-support date is coming up very soon and it's only just been made available for all eligible Windows 11 devices. This slightly older version of Windows had its own fair share of issues that Microsoft had to address, and this is possibly why it's taken this long for Microsoft to expand its availability to all eligible users.", "source": {"uri": "techradar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TechRadar"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kristina_terech@techradar.com", "name": "Kristina Terech", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "image": "https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/6dzurcbnjMdza8CXZM9XXe-1200-80.jpg", "eventUri": "eng-9736998", "sentiment": 0.05098039215686279, "wgt": 459007184, "relevance": 13}

{"url": "https://distrowatch.com/dwres.php?resource=showheadline&story=18415", "title": "SUSE gaining ground in the enterprise market, asks openSUSE to rebrand", "body": "SUSE gaining ground in the enterprise market, asks openSUSE to rebrand FOSS Force recently ran an article which suggested SUSE is starting to replace Red Hat as the standard bearer for enterprise Linux. In part this is due to Red Hat's mishandling of CentOS and SUSE's willingness to not only support its own products for longer periods of time, but to also support Red Hat's former products past their normal end of life dates. This gives SUSE an air of stability and predictability. However, at the same time, not everything is running smoothly in the SUSE and openSUSE communities. SUSE has apparently asked openSUSE to change its name (again) and there are concerns openSUSE doesn't currently have the goverance in place to effectively manage its own project. The issues are being discussed in a mailing list thread. \"Let me first define a couple of things that the community is being faced with: Our current governance is not working. {"url": "https://securityboulevard.com/?p=2024758", "title": "ESET: Chinese Adware Opens Windows Systems to More Threats", "body": "Malware aimed at Chinese-speaking people that passed itself off as a tool for improving the web browsing experience by blocking ads and malicious websites not only changed the content of a requested page or steered users to another one but also collected system information and allowed other bad actors to escalate privileges and run malicious code in Windows systems.\n\nResearchers with cybersecurity firm ESET noted that most security products detected the embedded HotPage installer - which was signed by Microsoft - as adware, but that a look under the hood revealed more sinister capabilities.\n\nThe malware illustrates the lengths to which bad actors will go to slip their malicious code into systems and some of the inherent weaknesses in security models, according to Romain Dumont, malware researcher at ESET.\n\n\"The HotPage driver reminds us that abusing Extended Verification certificates is still a thing,\" Dumont wrote in a report Thursday. \"As a lot of security models are at some point based on trust; threat actors are inclined to play along the line between legitimate and shady. Whether such software is advertised as a security solution or simply bundled with other software, the capabilities granted thanks to this trust expose users to security risks.\"\n\nESET at the end of 2023 came across the HotPage malware, which was being detected by security products as adware. However, researchers looked into the embedded driver that had been signed by Microsoft, finding it was developed by a Chinese company called Hubei Dunwang Network Technology Co., an organization they could find little information about.\n\nThe software was advertised as an \"internet café security solution\" for Chinese-speaking individuals and claiming to block ads and dangerous websites. What the researchers found was a dangerous piece of multi-faceted malware.\n\n\"On top of its obvious mischievous behavior, this kernel component unintentionally leaves the door open for other threats to run code at the highest privilege level available in the Windows operating system: the SYSTEM account,\" Dumont wrote. \"Due to improper access restrictions to this kernel component, any processes can communicate with it and leverage its code injection capability to target any non-protected processes.\"\n\nESET reported the driver to Microsoft March 18 and the driver was removed from the Windows Server Catalog May 1.\n\nWhen executed the HotPage malware loads the driver onto Windows, a process that since the 64-bit version of Windows 7 has required a signature from Microsoft. The security and compatibility process is built on trust and has been abused, he wrote. The Chinese company went through the steps and obtained an Extended Verification certificate.\n\nThe company submitted its drivers under various product categories and appears to have developed two network filtering programs - a netfilter and the HotPage driver, which is referred to as adsafe. Investigating the Chinese company online, the researchers only found that it was created in January 2022, had an email address, and offered tech-related activities like development, services, and consulting, as well as advertising functions. Its primary shareholder is a small Chinese ad and marketing company. A website was created in February 2022 and a couple of months later the company applied for the trade name Shield Internet Café Security Defense.\n\nIt's still unclear how the HotPage malware is distributed, though it may come bundled with another software package or advertised as a security product.\n\n\"The installer drops the driver on disk and starts a service to execute it,\" Dumont wrote. \"It decrypts its configuration file, which contains a list of target Chromium-based browsers and libraries. If such executables are found running or being loaded, the driver tries to inject one of the listed libraries into the browser process. After hooking network-based Windows API functions, the injected library checks the URL being accessed and under certain conditions, it displays another page to the user through diverse means.\"\n\nThe installer comes as a UPX-compressed file and includes the encrypted versions of the driver, libraries that will be injected into the browser processes and three JSON-formatted configuration files that contain targeted browsers and libraries, filtering rules, an API endpoint for sending details about the system and another for managing configuration updates.\n\nThe malware checks to see if it's running in a virtualized environment, decrypts the driver, creates a name followed by the .sys extension, and then a service to load the driver. It targets endpoints, collects information like the computer name, network interface MAC address, version of the operating system, and screen dimensions, then sends the information to a remote server through a HTTP POST request.\n\nThe driver injects libraries via the open source Blackbone Project into browser applications and alters their execution flow to change the URL being accessed by the user or opens a page in a new tab. Notification routine are set to monitor newly created processes and executable images that are downloaded.\n\nThe ESET researchers developed a proof-of-concept Python script that proved two scenarios where individuals could be allowed to escalate their privileges through the HotPage driver to run code as the NT AUTHORITY/Systems. One involved using arbitrary DLL injection in arbitrary processes, the other changing the command line of newly created processes.\n\nThe adware itself can be annoying, Dumont wrote, adding that the malware delivers more dangerous threats by allowing an attacker with a non-privileged account to use the driver to obtain SYSTEM privileges or introduced libraries into remote processes, causing further damage.\n\n\"The analysis of this rather generic-looking piece of malware has proven, once again, that adware developers are still willing to go the extra mile to achieve their goals,\" he wrote. \"Not only that, these have developed a kernel component with a large set of techniques to manipulate processes, but they also went through the requirements imposed by Microsoft to obtain a code-signing certificate for their driver component.\"", "source": {"uri": "securityboulevard.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Security Boulevard"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jeffrey_burt@securityboulevard.com", "name": "Jeffrey Burt", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "image": "https://securityboulevard.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/canstockphoto14662879.jpg", "eventUri": null, "sentiment": -0.02745098039215688, "wgt": 459006852, "relevance": 50}
{"url": "https://3dnews.ru/1108152/microsoft-vvodit-obnovleniya-s-kontrolnimi-tochkami-dlya-windows-11-eto-umenshit-razmer-paketov-i-uskorit-protsess-ustanovki", "title": "Microsoft введёт для Windows 11 обновления с контрольными точками  --  это уменьшит размер пакетов и ускорит установку", "body": "Компания Microsoft анонсировала изменение в концепции распространения накопительных обновлений для операционной системы Windows 11. Начиная с Windows 11 24H2, пользователи будут получать так называемые \"накопительные обновления с контрольными точками\", которые, как ожидается, будут более компактными и стабильными, а также будут устанавливаться быстрее и не потребуют каких-либо действий со стороны пользователей или IT-администраторов.\n\nИсточник изображений: techspot.com\n\nПо сути, накопительные обновления на основе контрольных точек будут включать в себя изменения, которые произошли с момента создания последней контрольной точки, а не с момента выхода RTM-сборки ОС. По мнению Microsoft, такой подход позволит пользователям экономить время и место на диске компьютера. Этот процесс может включать в себя создание нескольких контрольных точек в течение жизненного цикла сборки. В конечном счёте Microsoft хочет добиться уменьшения объёма загружаемых на устройства с Windows пакетов обновлений, а также более устойчивого перераспределения обновлений внутри организаций и более эффективного распространения ежегодных функциональных обновлений.\n\nАдминистраторы, получающие обновления из каталога Microsoft Update Catalog, увидят изменения в представлении доступных пакетов. Ежемесячные обновления могут содержать несколько пакетов -- по одному для каждой контрольной точки, а также дополнительный файл с накопительными обновлениями из последней контрольной точки. Их нужно будет устанавливать последовательно с помощью имеющихся инструментов развёртывания.\n\nНекоторые пользователи уже выразили опасения по поводу того, что новая схема распространения обновлений ещё больше усложнит и без того непростую систему обновлений. Не исключено, что пользователям будет сложнее откатить состояние ОС, если после установки какого-либо пакета возникнут проблемы. Кроме того, всегда есть вероятность возникновения конфликтов между разными обновлениями с контрольными точками или с существующими конфигурациями системы.\n\nЕсли же отбросить опасения, то преимущества более маленьких и быстрых обновлений перевешивают возможные недостатки. К тому же, Microsoft намерена сделать переход на новую схему как можно более плавным. Пользователи, которые хотят попробовать новую функцию, могут присоединиться к программе предварительной оценки Windows Insider на канале Dev и установить сборку Windows Insider Preview под номером 26120.1252.\n\nЕсли вы заметили ошибку -- выделите ее мышью и нажмите CTRL+ENTER. {"url": "https://www.unian.net/techno/communications/luchshiy-brauzer-2024-chrome-edge-i-drugie-sravnili-po-skorosti-12700839.html", "title": "Эксперты проверили скорость 6 главных браузеров и определили самый быстрый", "body": "Google Chrome, ожидаемо, оказался самым быстрым, но он имеет один весомый недостаток, отметили тестеры.\n\nПопулярное издание о техно, PCWorld, провело тестирование браузеров, чтобы сравнить их основные возможности и определить самые быстрые из них. За пьедестал боролись Edge, Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Brave и Vivaldi.\n\nТестирование проводилось на среднестатистическом компьютере 2024 года: процессор AMD Ryzen 5 3600, видеокарта Nvidia RTX 3060 Ti, 16 ГБайт ОЗУ, накопитель Samsung 970 Evo и операционная система Windows 10.\n\nГлавным критерием была скорость загрузки страницы, особенно тех, которые изобилуют графикой и элементами JavaScript. Для этого использовались инструменты Speedometer 3.0, Jetstream2 и Motionmark 1.3. Результаты оказались следующими:\n\nКак видно, явного победителя не оказалось. Однако Chrome один раз занял первое место и дважды пришел вторым. Вместе с тем, ему не хватило всего нескольких очков, чтобы стать лидером трижды. В совокупной скорости ему пока нет равных, заключили в PC World.\n\nНезависимо от того, являетесь ли вы обычным пользователем или продвинутым юзеров, в интернете Chrome почти всегда быстрее. Но высокоскоростной браузер тоже имеет несколько недостатков, которые выходят за рамки его скорости: бизнес-модель Google основана на обработке данных, и компания неоднократно подвергалась критике за сбор пользовательских данных - PC World.\n\nВ противоположность, Firefox занял последние места в тестах, зато он делает защиту пользовательских данных приоритетом. Он показал неплохие результаты в обработке веб-страниц (Speedometer), но в целом его быстродействие отстает от конкурентов.\n\nКак рассказывал УНИАН, недавно на Windows вышел веб-браузер, который обозреватели называют \"заменой Chrome, которую мы так долго ждали\". {"url": "https://www.theregister.com/2024/07/18/russias_fin7_is_peddling_its/", "title": "FIN7 is peddling its EDR-nerfing malware to ransomware gangs", "body": "Prolific Russian cybercrime syndicate FIN7 is using various pseudonyms to sell its custom security solution-disabling malware to different ransomware gangs.\n\nAvNeutralizer malware was previously thought to be solely linked to the Black Basta group, but fresh research has uncovered various underground forum listings of the malicious software now believed to be created by FIN7 operatives.\n\nCybercriminals would specify the specific endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions they wanted to bypass, and then a custom builder would be provided for them...\n\nPrices range between $4,000 and $15,000 and evidence suggests that AvNeutralizer has been marketed since at least 2022, with a surge in engagements involving FIN7's tool appearing in early 2023.\n\nSentinelOne's researchers said the malware is effective at disabling endpoint security products from its own portfolio and Windows Defender, as well as Sophos, Panda Security, Elastic, and Symantec.\n\nBlack Basta was spotted using AvNeutralizer a couple of years ago, but various other ransomware campaigns which started in 2023 began using the malware to evade detection too.\n\nCriminals using well-known ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) variants such as LockBit, ALPHV/BlackCat, Trigona, AvosLocker, and Medusa all showed they found value in AvNeutralizer, although concrete links between FIN7 and these RaaS operations haven't been firmly established.\n\nWhen purchasing the tool from what SentinelOne now believes to be pseudonyms adopted by FIN7, cybercriminals would specify the specific endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions they wanted to bypass, and then a custom builder would be provided for them.\n\n\"Considering the available evidence and prior intelligence, we assess with high confidence that 'goodsoft,' 'lefroggy,' 'killerAV' and 'Stupor' [personas] belong to the FIN7 cluster,\" said Antonio Cocomazzi, staff offensive security researcher at SentinelOne, in a blog this week.\n\n\"Furthermore, these threat actors are likely employing multiple pseudonyms on various forums to mask their true identity and sustain their illicit operations within this network.\"\n\nAvNeutralizer is also under continuous development and has proven to be a mainstay of FIN7's arsenal of tools, which include backdoors, PowerShell scripts, and pentesting kits.\n\nThe most recent version, the earliest sighting of which was dated April 2023, introduced a novel tampering technique using ProcLaunchMon.sys, a built-in TTD monitor driver in Windows, to create a denial of service condition in specific processes.\n\nThe full details of how FIN7 crashes EDR solutions are detailed in SentinelOne's blog but in essence, it suspends the child processes of targeted protected processes. The latter then fails because they can no longer communicate with the former.\n\nIt should also be said that this isn't a catch-all method to kill EDR processes - more than ten other user mode and kernel mode techniques are used to bust top security solutions. These are all well-documented already, though.\n\nSentinelOne said that now it has a clearer understanding of AvNeutralizer, how it is marketed and who is using it, the team is able to track malicious activity more accurately and carry out better-informed retrospective analyses.\n\nFIN7 has been in play since 2012 and over the past 12 years it has continually evolved tactics from the early days of deploying point-of-sale (PoS) card-stealing malware to becoming a fully fledged ransomware gang in 2020.\n\nAt times it has been affiliated with the likes of REvil and Conti, but also went on to form its own RaaS operation in the form of Darkside, which later rebranded to BlackMatter after it hit Colonial Pipeline.\n\nWhen its members weren't trying to conceal themselves behind an array of pseudonyms, they were creating fake companies, such as Combi Security and Bastion Secure, to conceal their actions and hire unwitting IT professionals to help them set up ransomware attacks. It didn't work out too well for some of them.\n\nDespite the numerous arrests of FIN7 members over the years, the group strides on to this day and continues to evolve, making the task of attribution that more important.\n\n\"FIN7's continuous innovation, particularly in its sophisticated techniques for evading security measures, showcases its technical expertise,\" said Cocomazzi.\n\n\"The group's use of multiple pseudonyms and collaboration with other cybercriminal entities makes attribution more challenging and demonstrates its advanced operational strategies. We hope this research will inspire further efforts to understand and mitigate FIN7's evolving tactics.\" ®", "source": {"uri": "theregister.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "theregister.com"}, "authors": [], "image": "https://regmedia.co.uk/2017/10/20/security_shutterstock.jpg", "eventUri": "eng-9744044", "sentiment": 0.2470588235294118, "wgt": 459006228, "relevance": 26}

{"url": "https://www.fayerwayer.com/internet/2024/07/18/tiembla-canva-asi-funciona-la-designer-app-de-microsoft-potenciada-por-inteligencia-artificial/", "title": "Tiembla Canva | Así funciona la Designer app de Microsoft potenciada por Inteligencia Artificial", "body": "En el mundo del diseño gráfico podríamos decir que Photoshop y Adobe con toda su Suite, al igual que otras alternativas más accesibles y sencillas de usar, como Canva, se han convertido en referente obligado para todos a nivel global. En introduisant des checkpoints.\n\nMicrosoft compte mettre cette approche en œuvre d'ici à la fin de l'année. Il en donne un aperçu sur le canal Dev (build 26210.1252)*.\n\nÀ l'heure actuelle, les mises à jour mensuelles dites \" de qualité \" (diffusées lors Patch Tuesday) sont construites de façon cumulative à partir de la RTM du système d'exploitation : chacune inclut tous les changements intervenus depuis lors.\n\nLes mises à jour \" checkpoint \" se fonderont non pas sur la RTM, mais sur le précédent checkpoint.
